ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: three days of synchronous classes (Monday, Wednesday, Friday) followed by two days of asynchronous classes (Tuesday, Thursday)

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I developed the ability to speak Spanish.

A good breadth of Spanish grammar fundamentals, along with as much of the textbook vocab as you can cram into your head. By the end of the semester, I felt like I had the grammar and expression-based fundamentals to have a "flow" when expressing moderately advanced concepts, and I had the vocab to handle basic-moderate situations at will.
I learned how to converse in Spanish at the introductory level, as well as discuss topics such as homes, neighborhoods, giving directions, food, etc.

I learned the basics of Spanish grammar and vocabulary that helped create the foundation for the years of Spanish acquisition to follow. I became better at reading, writing, and conversing in Spanish.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths: The 3x weekly meetings + 2x asynchronous activities were a great balance between studying everyday and avoiding Zoom fatigue. Virtual Spanish went a lot better than expected.

Strengths: a wide variety of ways to engage with the language, classes are engaging
Weaknesses: one of the (graded) homework assignments rely heavily on Supersite, which oftentimes takes off points for correct answers.

This was overall a very difficult course. It is considered two credits, so there is a lot of work you have to do, both in and out of class. Yet from the class, you will learn so much about not only the Spanish language but also the culture. A weakness was the overall difficulty of the course, I would recommend any looking into the course to have either already some knowledge of the language or a lot of experience in learning foreign languages.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Group/partner activities outside of class were hit or miss.
The breakout rooms were great, as well as the discussion format in class to allow you to verbally engage with the text. Nothing to be improved, except perhaps a lower workload.

Most of the practices geared towards the pandemic greatly helped me. I would recommend including more outside work to do with a partner from the class. Because everything was virtual, it was a lot harder to get to know the classmates.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes. Don't fear the intensive course; if the regular course goes at half the speed of the intensive course, I would consider the regular course too slow.
Yes! Retainment/consistency would've been better if we hadn't been limited with regards to class time, but hopefully that's a quarantine-only quirk limited to this year.

Yes, I would recommend this course to another student, given that they are HIGHLY motivated to learn the language or already have a background in Spanish. The class is extremely fast-paced and all the classes are conducted in Spanish which can be a lot for beginners to handle.
